channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: 7 Teenage Deaths, but No Answers for Aboriginal Canadians
item.media:description: Christian Morriseau stands between the graves of his son Kyle and his father, Norval Morrisseau (some family members have altered the spelling of their last name), in Keewaywin First Nation, north of Thunder Bay, Ontario. Mr. Morriseau’s son was one of seven youths who died mysteriously while attending high school in Thunder Bay.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: Seven students attending school far from home were found dead over more than a decade, but an coroner’s inquest could not determine why.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Tribunal Rejects Beijing’s Claims in South China Sea
item.description: An international panel in The Hague delivered a sweeping rebuke of China’s behavior, deciding that its expansive claim to sovereignty over the waters had no legal basis.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Theresa May’s Style: Put Your Head Down and Get to Work
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II on Wednesday welcomed Theresa May, left, at the start of an audience in Buckingham Palace, where she invited Ms. May to become prime minister and form a new government.
item.description: Britain’s new prime minister is widely seen as a safe pair of hands, but the times may demand that she be both steady and bold.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Goran Hadzic, Ex-Leader of Rebel Serbs in Croatia, Dies at 58
item.media:description: Goran Hadzic in Okucani, Croatia, in 1993. Arrested in 2011, he was freed last year.
item.description: Mr. Hadzic was arrested in 2011 and faced war crimes charges, but he was released last year because he had terminal brain cancer.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia

item.title: Bernardo Provenzano, ‘Boss of Bosses’ of Sicilian Mafia, Is Dead at 83
item.media:description: Bernardo Provenzano, center, escorted by police officers in Palermo, Sicily, after his arrest in 2006. He had spent four decades as a fugitive.
item.description: Mr. Provenzano managed to elude the Italian police for four decades before being captured in 2006.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: Cease-Fire Appears to Hold in South Sudan’s Capital, Juba
item.description: Hours after a truce was reached to end fighting between rival groups of soldiers, thousands of civilians remained in churches and schools out of fear and uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: What Can the United Nations Do When its Troops Can’t, or Won’t, Protect Civilians?
item.media:description: A United Nations peacekeeper from Rwanda amid the remnants of a looted and burned clinic at the camp in Malakal, South Sudan, in February. The massacre there emerged as a test of recent United Nations pledges.
item.media:credit: Albert Gonzalez Farran/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The United Nations Security Council says it wants peacekeepers to protect civilians in South Sudan, but it faces blistering criticism there.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Iran Sticks to Terms of Nuclear Deal, but Defies the U.S. in Other Ways
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif of Iran, center left, and Secretary of State John Kerry, center right, during nuclear talks in Lausanne, Switzerland, in April 2015.
item.description: The worst predictions of what would happen under the deal have not come to pass, but very little outside the strict confines of the agreement has improved.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: ‘We Live in a Society Where the Word “Liberal” Is Considered an Insult’
item.media:description: Friday prayer at the Fahed bin Saidaan mosque in Ryadh.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Saudis and others who have lived there respond to an article in The New York Times about the practice of Islam in the kingdom.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: A Saudi Morals Enforcer Called for a More Liberal Islam. Then the Death Threats Began.
item.media:description: Saudi women standing on the opposite side of the hall from the men at the Amex Luxury Expo in Riyadh in March.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: A longtime morals enforcer began to question the rules. He told his story to a Times correspondent who spent weeks in Saudi Arabia trying to understand its hyper-conservative strain of Islam, which is often blamed for terrorism.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Eye Injuries Flood Kashmir Hospitals After Police Fire Pellets at Protesters
item.media:description: A man lay in a hospital in Srinagar, Kashmir, on Wednesday after being hit by live ammunition fired by security forces during a protest.
item.description: More than 30 people have been killed during demonstrations since Saturday, authorities said, and more than 2,000 injured, including some with severe eye trauma.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: The Mirrors Behind Rembrandt’s Self-Portraits
item.media:description: A Rembrandt self-portrait. A new study offered further evidence for the hypothesis that the Dutch painter and other “old masters” used optics to create their portraits.
item.media:credit: National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C.
item.description: A new paper outlines optical techniques that the 17th-century Dutch painter may have used to make accurate self-portraits.
item.dc:creator: STEPH YIN

item.title: United Nations Assailed in Report by Kosovo Rights Panel
item.media:description: A refugee camp in Mitrovica, Kosovo, in 2007.
item.description: The panel said its effort to make the United Nations Interim Administration Mission in Kosovo accountable for rights violations had been a “total failure.”
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Zimbabwe Court Frees Pastor Detained Over Protests Against Mugabe
item.media:description: The Rev. Evan Mawarire addressed supporters after his release at Harare Magistrates Court on Wednesday.
item.description: A court ruled that the state’s efforts to increase the severity of charges against the pastor, the Rev. Evan Mawarire, were unconstitutional.
item.dc:creator: HOPEWELL CHIN’ONO and NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Sinosphere: China, Sweltering, Doles Out Subsidies for High Heat
item.media:description: A construction site in Beijing. Many people who work outdoors are eligible for a subsidy if temperatures exceed 95 degrees.
item.description: By law, many people who work outdoors are eligible for a subsidy whenever temperatures exceed 95 degrees Fahrenheit.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: A Haircut for French Taxpayers? Hollande’s $10,000-a-Month Stylist Is Revealed
item.media:description: President François Hollande, center left, at the Élysée Palace in Paris after cabinet meeting on Wednesday.
item.description: Revelations that President François Hollande’s hairdresser is paid about as much as a government minister have caused a stir in France.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: ‘All Possibilities’ Under Investigation in Italian Train Crash
item.media:description: Train debris on Wednesday at the site of a collision between the towns of Andria and Corato, in the southern Italian region of Puglia. About two dozen people were killed.
item.description: The chief prosecutor said human error was only “a starting point” in the inquiry as the operation of that stretch of railway came under heavy criticism.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Beijing Protests South China Sea Ruling With Modest Show of Strength
item.media:description: Chinese police officers blocked the road leading to the Philippine Embassy in Beijing on Tuesday and Wednesday.
item.description: Two civilian planes went to artificial islands in the waterway, but warships were not sent there after the Philippines won its case against China’s claim.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: European Court Backs Woman Dismissed in France for Wearing Head Scarf
item.media:description: In France, public servants are barred from wearing garments or conspicuous insignia that display religious beliefs, such as a head scarf or a skullcap.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: The advisory opinion released by the European Court of Justice does not fully settle the fraught issue of religious attire in the workplace.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Jerusalem Journal: For Palestinians, Raising Arabian Horses Is ‘the Hobby of the Poor’
item.media:description: Alaa Mustafa, 24, trains an Arabian horse named Rawnaq at a stable in the neighborhood of Issawiya.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: Stables dot villages and towns of every size in the occupied West Bank, and many families who share tiny, cramped homes raise their own horses.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ and RAMI NAZZAL

item.title: China Pledged to Curb Coal Plants. Greenpeace Says It’s Still Adding Them.
item.media:description: A coal-fired plant in Guangzhou, China. The country has 910 gigawatts of coal-fired capacity and is expected to retire 70 gigawatts of that.
item.description: The construction boom would result in about 400 gigawatts of excess capacity and waste more than $150 billion on building unneeded plants, the group said in a report.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Emperor Akihito of Japan Plans to Abdicate Throne, Broadcaster Says
item.media:description: Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko at the Akasaka Palace imperial garden in Tokyo in April.
item.description: According to the country’s public broadcaster, the emperor told close aides that he intended to pass the throne to his son, Crown Prince Naruhito, before he dies.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Emmanuel Macron, French Economy Minister, Hints at Presidential Run
item.media:description: Economy Minister Emmanuel Macron of France at a political rally on Tuesday in Paris for his “On Our Way” campaign.
item.description: The re-election prospects for President François Hollande clouded further as Mr. Macron all but stepped into the ring.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Egypt’s Latest Tactic Against Critics: Block Their Movements, or Deport Them
item.media:description: The Lebanese-British journalist Liliane Daoud in 2014.
item.description: Liliane Daoud, a Lebanese-British journalist who was sent to Beirut, Lebanon, in June, is one of many people who say they have been barred from the country.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: The Interpreter: Maybe North Korea’s Nuclear Goals Are More Serious Than Once Thought
item.media:description: Thousands of North Koreans attended a rally last month to remember the start of the Korean War, holding banners that called for the defense of Kim Jong-un, the nation’s leader.
item.description: The country’s weapons programs have long been understood as meant for propaganda, not military, purposes. That view might be dangerously wrong.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: E.U. Offers New Immigration Plan, Hoping to Sway Reluctant Countries
item.media:description: Paramedics escort migrants rescued on Wednesday off the coast of Lesbos, Greece, after their dinghy capsized.
item.description: The European Union authorities offered a series of proposals that reflected a renewed effort to impose clearer rules for both member states and migrants.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: South Korean Villagers Protest Plans for U.S. Missile Defense System
item.media:description: Thousands of residents in the town of Seongju, South Korea, on Wednesday holding up banners opposing the deployment of the Terminal High-Altitude Area Defense system there.
item.media:credit: Yonhap, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Thousands of residents of a rural county protested its selection as the site of the so-called Thaad system, which China has also bitterly opposed.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Theresa May, New British Prime Minister, Gives Boris Johnson a Key Post
item.description: Ms. May quickly put her stamp on the new government by appointing Mr. Johnson as foreign secretary and Philip Hammond as chancellor of the Exchequer.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: NBCUniversal Executive Is Denied Entry Into Russia
item.media:description: Jeff Shell
item.description: Jeff Shell, who oversees the company’s motion picture unit and is chairman of the federal agency that oversees Voice of America and Radio Free Europe, was detained and then sent away.
item.dc:creator: RON NIXON and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Taiwan, After Rejecting South China Sea Decision, Sends Patrol Ship
item.media:description: Tsai Ing-wen, center, the president of Taiwan, meeting with officers on a warship in the southern city of Kaohsiung on Wednesday before it headed for Itu Aba, controlled by Taiwan.
item.media:credit: Taiwan Defence Ministry, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Taiwan’s claims in the contested waters match China’s, but it has not pushed them as aggressively as its neighbor and rival.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Trilobites: After 300 Years of Collecting, Nearly 12,000 Amazon Tree Species Are Found
item.media:description: The Putumayo basin of Loreto, Peru, located within the Amazonian forest.
item.description: Researchers analyzed hundreds of thousands of samples in digitized museum collections to produce an estimate of species in the South American rain forest.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: Two Hostages From Bangladesh Standoff Are Still Missing
item.media:description: Tahmid Hasib Khan, in a photo provided by his family, remains missing after being detained by Dhaka police following an attack on a restaurant in Dhaka, Bangladesh.
item.description: Amnesty International urged the government to clarify the whereabouts of one of the men, who were questioned after surviving a terrorist attack on a Dhaka restaurant.
item.dc:creator: MAHER SATTAR and GEETA ANAND
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: David Cameron Gets Hustled Out of Downing Street, but the Cat Stays
item.media:description: Theresa May, Britain’s incoming prime minister, walked past Larry the Cat on her way to attend a cabinet meeting at 10 Downing Street in London on Tuesday.
item.description: The only resident of 10 Downing Street to be spared the indignity of one of Britain’s fastest political transitions in recent memory will be Larry the Cat.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: News Analysis: Theresa May, Untested and Ascending to Manage ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: Theresa May leaving 10 Downing Street after attending a cabinet meeting there on Tuesday.
item.description: No one is quite sure if Ms. May, the next British prime minister, can successfully balance the nation’s economic and political needs with the exit from the European Union.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Thousands Protest Sex Assaults at Bull Run in Pamplona, Spain
item.media:description: Protesting sexual violence against women during the San Fermín festival in Pamplona, Spain.
item.description: Fifteen people have been arrested in separate cases of sexual assault at the annual San Fermín festival, amid heightened awareness of such attacks in Europe.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn Will Be on Ballot as Labour Party Schedules Election in Britain
item.media:description: Jeremy Corbyn, the leader of the opposition Labour Party, in London on Tuesday. He had campaigned for Britain to remain in the European Union.
item.description: Mr. Corbyn faced a revolt by fellow Labour lawmakers after Britain’s June 23 referendum to leave the European Union.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN and RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Pastor in Zimbabwe Is Arrested as Anger Toward Robert Mugabe Builds
item.media:description: The Rev. Evan Mawarire, second from right, who organized an antigovernment protest last week, arriving on Tuesday at a police station in Harare, Zimbabwe.
item.description: The activism of the Rev. Evan Mawarire, who organized the country’s largest protests in a decade, has galvanized public outrage over the president’s rule.
item.dc:creator: HOPEWELL CHIN’ONO and NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Memo From Paris: ‘That Ignoramus’: 2 French Scholars of Radical Islam Turn Bitter Rivals
item.media:description: Muslims gathered last month in Mantes-La-Jolie, France, a Paris suburb, for a walk in tribute to two victims of a stabbing attack by an assailant claiming to act in the name of the Islamic State.
item.description: A falling-out between the academics, Olivier Roy and Gilles Kepel, presents an important question: Which man holds the key to understanding the phenomenon?
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: 5 Things to Know About Theresa May, Britain’s Next Prime Minister
item.media:description: Theresa May, the British home secretary, is poised to become the country’s next prime minister.
item.description: Ms. May is set to become the country’s leader on Wednesday. She’s been a long-serving cabinet minister and has promised to guide Britain out of the European Union.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Letter From Europe: Turkey Makes Overtures to Minorities, but Old Enmities Linger
item.media:description: The unfinished Statue of Humanity, a monument to Armenian-Turkish reconciliation, in Kars, Turkey, in 2009. It was demolished in 2011.
item.description: The government denies the Armenian genocide and threatens to punish countries that recognize it, but there are signs that history may be getting its due.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: Sinosphere: Beetle Is Named in Honor of Xi Jinping, but China Aims to Squash the News
item.media:description: The Rhyzodiastes (Temoana) xii, discovered last year on Hainan Island, was named for President Xi Jinping of China.
item.description: The taxonomic gesture appeared to irritate propaganda bosses, who moved fast to block references to the “Xi beetle” from the nation’s heavily censored internet
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Train Crash in Italy Leaves at Least 25 Dead and Dozens Injured
item.description: The crash occurred around 11:30 a.m. in an olive grove between Andria and Ruvo di Puglia, in the southern region of Puglia.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Korean Official, Calling for Class System, Hears Woofs, Oinks and Outrage
item.media:description: Prime Minister Hwang Kyo-ahn of South Korea
item.description: Comments online expressed anger at an education official who said the country should put in place a structure in which 99 percent of South Koreans should be treated “like dogs and pigs.”
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Europe Approves New Trans-Atlantic Data Transfer Deal
item.media:description: Penny Pritzker, left, the American secretary of commerce; and Vera Jourova, the European Union’s commissioner in charge of justice, consumers and gender equality, at a news briefing in Brussels on Tuesday after the approval of the new data pact.
item.description: After years of negotiations, Europe agreed to allow thousands of companies to move digital data to the United States, though challenges still lie ahead.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Amid Grim Economic Forecasts, Cubans Fear a Return to Darker Times
item.media:description: Baracoa, Cuba, in January. Addressing members of Parliament last week, Cuba’s economy minister, Marino Murillo, said the country would have to cut fuel consumption by nearly a third during the second half of the year.
item.description: Recent calls to cut energy usage, along with the faltering economy in Venezuela, which provides much of Cuba’s oil, have left Cubans worried about fuel shortages and blackouts.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT

item.title: What in the World: In New Zealand, Lands and Rivers Can Be People (Legally Speaking)
item.description: In a deal with Maori groups, Parliament has agreed on a way to protect natural features without them being owned by anyone, including the state.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: What in the World: At Mexico’s Top Restaurants, Service Too Good to Be Good
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; Photos by LuckyImages, sisqopote/shutterstock
item.description: At many of the country’s higher-end establishments, waiters are arguably so attentive it borders on annoying.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: What in the World: Kenya Mocks Its Woes in Wry Verbal Shorthand
item.description: The country’s understated humor comes through in popular Swahili and English euphemisms for life’s annoyances and sins.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Sinosphere: Tiananmen Protest Museum in Hong Kong Shuts Its Doors, for Now
item.media:description: A replica of the Goddess of Democracy statue at the June 4th Museum in Hong Kong, along with documents from the 1989 protests.
item.description: The museum, arguing that it had been forced out, said it was searching for a new site but had not found one in time to prevent a temporary closing.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China

item.title: Voices From Europe’s Far Right
item.media:description: “Our economy doesn’t increase along with the never-ending supply of immigrants,” wrote Mikael Jakobsen, 24, a law student in Aarhus, Denmark.
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of readers from across the Continent responded to our call to share their experiences as supporters of far-right parties.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Why the U.S. Military Can’t Fix Syria
item.media:description: Smoke rises from a U.S.-led coalition airstrike in Kobane, Syria, in 2014.
item.description: More American involvement in the Middle East’s biggest quagmire will definitely end badly.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN SIMON and JONATHAN STEVENSON
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Editorial: Theresa May to the Rescue
item.media:description: Theresa May and her husband Philip at 10 Downing Street in London, on Wednesday.
item.description: The new prime minister faces the tough task of creating a future for Britain outside the European Union.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why Putin Loves Brexit
item.description: In the Russian president’s view, what makes Europe weaker makes him stronger.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW FOXALL

item.title: As Refugee Family Resettles in Sweden, 9-Year-Old Nephew Dies
item.media:description: While a nurse prepares a medicine, Nabih, 9, rests in a hospital bed next to an aunt, his brother Farid and his mother Shazia Nouri, right, at a hospital in Antalya, southern Turkey.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Ahmad Majid is one of millions of people swept up in a global refugee crisis; his resettlement in Sweden ended when his young nephew died this week.
item.dc:creator: ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Insider Podcasts: Gone: Global Warming Claims a Lake — and a Way of Life
item.media:description: The dry bed of Lake Poopó near Llapallapani.
item.description: The Andes bureau chief, Nicholas Casey, and the staff photographer Josh Haner give listeners a behind-the-scenes account of their article about a vanished lake.
item.dc:creator: SUSAN LEHMAN

item.title: Srebrenica: 21st Anniversary of Europe’s Worst Postwar Massacre
item.description: More than 8,000 men and boys were murdered in and around the city of Srebrenica in July 1995, the worst mass killing in Europe since World War II.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
